evidence.text:
Person B: We said goodnight. And then I went upstairs and I stayed up late reading a book that Martha had recommended… it’s called Erotic Vagrancy… It’s about Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton. Do you know it?
Person B: Martha and I both thought it was a lot of fun.
Person A: What did you do the following morning?
Person B: I had lunch with a friend… And then, when I came back, I called out to her, and when she didn’t answer, I went straight to her bedroom, but she wasn’t there. So I went out to the back yard, and that’s when I saw her. At first, I thought she’d fallen asleep on the lounge chair… I got very nervous. I called the ambulance… They came pretty quickly and, when the EMTs saw her, they said there was nothing they could do.
Person B: About what?
Person A: About her being in possession of this illegal compound.
Person B: No… I mean… I know she was taking medication for the pain, but she never shared specifics with me…
Person A: Nobody buys this pill by accident unless they’re thinking of suicide or killing someone.
Person A: So… it is strange, if the two of you were
Person A: I think that when she rented the house, she already knew what she was going to do… right?
Person B: It’s very possible, but she didn’t tell me about it. She was exhausted from the last treatment, and she wanted to take a month off before going back for the next round of chemo… Martha wasn’t the type to throw in the towel.
Person A: She didn’t complain? She didn’t say anything that made you sense… the end? It’s a great responsibility for you.
Person B: She complained, sometimes…
Person A: What did she complain about? What did she say?
Person B: She’d lost the capacity for attention, she couldn’t read or write… for example. Her life had been reduced to surviving…
Person A: I find it very hard to believe she didn’t say anything… that made you suspect the end.
Person B: It was more than evident that she was very sick, but Martha wanted to go on vacation before going back to the hospital… I told you this already. I
